journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part J: Journal of Engineering Tribology

title-group.article-title: Study on the influence of critical shear stress on wall slip of spiral oil wedge journal bearing

article-meta.aff: School of Mechanical Engineering, Shandong University, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Chang-Hou Lu, School of Mechanical Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan, People’s Republic of China. Email: luchh@sdu.edu.cn

abstract.p: With the application of sleeve bearing in high speed, super-high speed and narrow-gap conditions, and the emergence of non-metallic bearing materials, the conventional no-slip boundary condition can be broken down. Critical shear stress is a main parameter in the numerical computation of wall slip. The four modified Reynolds equations for the two-dimensional spiral oil wedge sleeve bearing is established based on the critical shear stress model, in which the circumferential and axial wall slip of the sleeve and axial surface are considered. The shear stress angle is used to compute the circumferential and axial shear stress component and slip velocity. The results show the special structure of spiral oil wedge and the increase of eccentricity ratio make slip more difficult to occur. With the decrease of initial limiting shear stress, pressure, carrying capacity and friction drag decrease. Wall slip has an effect on the oil film rupture position, positive pressure area, and pressure peak. Wall slip occurs first in the large shear stress, the small clearance, and the envelop zone. The slip position and area influence each other in the sleeve and axial surface.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Hybrid journal bearing has been widely applied to high speed and precise spindle systems, due to the advantage of high load capacity, excellent keeping, and stability. The classical Reynolds equation assumes that the liquid molecules adjacent to the solid are stationary relative to the solid, which states that fluid at a solid surface has no relative velocity to it. With the use of sleeve bearings in high speed, ultra-high speed and the narrow-gap conditions, the application of non-metallic material bearing and the emergence of special lubricants, wall slip is a common phenomenon in lubrication. Recently, researchers have observed the occurrence of slip by theory and experiment. Choo et al.1,2 tested the friction coefficient with hydrophobic and hydrophilic surfaces and revealed that the lubricant slipped against the hydrophobic surface by a reduction in friction, but the slip did not occur against the hydrophilic surface. Their results have proved that hexadecane can show apparent slip against sapphire surfaces with critical shear stress of 30 Pa and slip length of 4 µm. Watanabe et al.3 learned the drag drop of tap water and an aqueous solution of glycerin flowing in pipes with highly water-repellent walls, the slip velocity that measured using a hot-film anemometer was directly proportional to the shear stress, sliding coefficient for fluids was a constant value, and the slip length of tap water flowing in a pipe was about 0.25–0.92 mm. Recently, it has been demonstrated that slip occurred on mica and glass surfaces, and the degree of slip was found to increase with surface roughness.4,5 Cho et al.6 examined the slip behavior for 13 categories of polar and non-polar liquids at alkylsilane-coated solid surfaces using the colloidal probe atomic force microscope technique. The results found that the slip length was not influenced by the contact angle and viscosity for polar liquids, but the slip length decreased with the decrease of contact angle for non-polar liquid. Craig et al.,7 Du et al.,8 and Ellis and Hayward9 demonstrated that the slip degree of aqueous solutions of sucrose, hydrophilic liquids, and water at the gold surfaces was different, and the slip length was measured. For hexadecane flowing on a lyophobic smooth surface, slip lengths of the order of 400 nm were obtained by Pit R et al.10 Zhu et al.11 implied that partial slip occurred when shear stress (shear rate) exceeded a critical level, slip occurred for deionized water on octadecyltriethoxysilane-coated partially wetting surfaces.

The critical shear stress model that proposes originally in the rheological behavior study of elastohydrodynamic lubrication problem12–14 is introduced to describe the boundary slip, and it assumes that wall slip occurs when shear stress exceeds the limiting shear stress at the solid–liquid interface. Kaneta et al.15 implied that wall slip and wall shear strength were closely related, and the liquid molecules will slip along the surface when the interfacial shear stress reached the critical shear stress. Salant and Fortier16 assumed that fluid slip occurred when a critical shear stress was exceeded, the resulting slip velocity was proportional to the difference between the shear stress and the critical value. The results showed that the slip region was the same as the effect of a recess, which reduced the resistance to flow. Spikes17,18 implied that fluid slip occurred when shear stress exceeded the limiting shear stress, and carrying capacity, friction drag of finite and infinite length slider bearing considering the wall slip were computed. Based on the limiting shear stress model and the corresponding finite element parametric quadratic programming method, Ma et al.19 studied the influence of wall slip on the hydrodynamic lubrication performance of a two-dimensional (2D) journal bearing. Reference has given the detailed numerical analyses on the boundary slip and hydrodynamics for different gap flows and revealed some new physical phenomena and rules. Especially, it was found that a heterogeneous boundary slip improved the hydrodynamic effects. Jin et al.20 proved the possibility of boundary slip between oil and surface of polymer of low surface energy by comparative experiments and implied that boundary slip occurred when shear stress up to a critical value. The results showed that the slip effect increased with the increase of shear stress and the decrease of field pressure. Spikes and Granick21 and Fatu Aurelian et al.22 implied that wall slip occurred when shear stress exceeded a critical level and the slip length was a constant value. The influence of wall slip over the load carrying capacity and power loss in hydrodynamic fluid bearings were studied. Comparing with the textured bearings, wall slip conditions leaded to better power loss improvements and higher carrying capacity. To study the boundary slippage effect on squeeze film, Guo and Wong23 presented that the pressure gradient can be discontinuous at the border of the slip and no-slip regions and the critical shear stress significantly affected the squeeze behavior.

From the numerical point of view, there are two slip models: the slip length model states that shear stress varies in proportion to the slip velocity, and the critical shear stress model states shear stress varies with local pressure.1,18 Although many literatures prove the existence of slip, but few measure the specific critical shear stress. Based on the slip length model τc=ηbus, the critical shear stress of hexadecane at lyophobic surfaces was 5 kPa, and the critical shear stress of deionized water on octadecyltriethoxysilane-coated partially wetting surfaces was 0.1 Pa.17,18 Ma et al.19 demonstrated that the critical shear stress was 0.3 kPa for aqueous solutions of sucrose flowing on a 15.1 nm thickness of gold film coated the sphere and flat walls, the critical shear stress was 6 Pa for tetradecane to which 0.2% of hexadecylamine was added flowing on the mica wall. The critical shear stress of oil at EMP journal bearing surfaces was 1.12694 kPa, which was obtained by Jin et al.20 So the study on the influence of critical shear stress on wall slip is very necessary.

Most slip analysis is based on 1D circumferential direction slip, but the wall slip analysis of 2D and complex flow is seldom. The values of critical shear stress are also different if work environment, friction materials, and lubricants are different. In this article, spiral oil wedge hybrid sleeve bearing (Figure 1) is studied, its outstanding features of the bearing are as follows: three arc oil recesses on whole circumference are titled and the bearing has oil feed holes and oil return holes at both ends of each recess. So the different structures of this new bearing make its static and dynamic characteristics and slip properties different from conventional bearings. By means of the finite differential methods, the influence of critical shear stress on slip characteristics of 2D journal bearing considering the circumferential and axial wall slip is studied. Figure 1.
The structural diagram of spiral oil wedge hydrodynamic bearing.

sec.title: Velocity boundary conditions
sec.p:
Wall slip occurs when shear stress exceeds the critical shear stress at the solid–liquid interface. Figure 2 illustrates that the flow of liquid can be regarded as an infinite number of very thin liquid layer and the internal friction of the liquid can be expressed using the shear stress that is caused by relative sliding of the liquid layer. Wall slip occurs when shear stress of sleeve surface exceeds the critical shear stress at the solid–liquid interface, then shear stress and slip velocities in the x- and z-directions can be expressed as τyx = τculx, u = usb and τyz = τculz, w = wsb, respectively.1,14,17,19 In addition to sleeve interface, shear stress τyx in the x-direction can be expressed as τyx=η∂u/∂y, shear stress τyz in the z-direction can be expressed as τyz=η∂w/∂y for the rest of the thin layer interface. Figure 2.
Shear stress.

Figure 3 shows that the liquid molecules adjacent to the solid are not stationary relative to the solid when wall slip occurs on sleeve surface, while they move with speeds usb and wsb in the x- and z-directions, respectively. Considering the slip region on the stationary surface of the journal bearing, the boundary conditions for the steady flow at the axis surface (y = 0) and the sleeve surface (y = h) are as follows1,14,17,19 (1) where z is the axial coordinate, x the circumferential coordinate, y the radial coordinate, usb, wsb the slip velocity of sleeve surface in x- and z-directions, τculx, τculz the critical shear stress of sleeve surface in the x- and z-directions, τyx, τyz the shear stress in the x- and z-directions, and βculx, βculz the sign function. Figure 3.
Slip velocity at the sleeve surface.

sec.title: Generalized Reynolds equation considering wall slip
sec.p: It is assumed that the flow is incompressible, constant viscosity, laminar, and the lubricant inertia effect is small. Substituting equation (1) into simplified Navier–Stokes equation, the velocity equation can be expressed as follows (2)
A similar expression can be derived for the z-direction (3)
The volumetric flow rate through per unit width on film cross-section as (4)
The shear stress equation in the x-direction is equation (2) differential (5)
A similar expression can be derived for the z-direction (6)
Substituting equation (4) into continuity of flow, the Reynolds equation is then modified to account for the wall slip of sleeve surface as follows (7)
For equation (7), the satisfied condition is as follows14
A similar expression can be derived for the Reynolds equation considering the wall slip of axis surface (8)
For equation (8), the satisfied condition is as follows τb < τcdl, τb<τcul

Figure 4 shows that wall slip occurs on sleeve surface and axis surface, then velocities of sleeve surface in the x- and z-directions are usb and wsb, respectively; velocities of axis surface in the x- and in the z-directions are ua + usa and wsa, respectively. The Reynolds equation is then modified to account for the wall slip of sleeve and axis surfaces as follows (9) Figure 4.
Slip velocity at the sleeve and axis surface.
For equation (9), the satisfied condition is as follows τa < τcdl, τb>τcul
When wall slip cannot be considered, the Reynolds equation can be expressed as follows (10)
For equation (10), the satisfied condition is as follows τa < τcdl, τb<τcul

where p is the oil film pressure, η the fluid dynamic viscosity, h the oil film thickness, ua the journal speed, usa, wsa the slip velocity in the x- and z-directions at axial surface, βcdlx, βcdlz the sign function, τa the shear stress at axial surface, τb the shear stress at sleeve surface, τcu, τcd the initial shear stress for slip at sleeve and axis surface, kcu, kcd the pressure constant, k¯cu=Rkcu/c,k¯cd=Rkcd/c,k¯cu,k¯cd the 0.17 based on the results of literatures,14,19 c the bearing clearance, R the bearing radius, τcdl, τcul the critical shear stress for slip at axial and sleeve surface.

sec.title: Slip velocity
sec.p: For equations (7) to (9), the slip velocity is an unknown term, it can be obtained by the following formula (11) (12)
The similar expression can be derived for the slip velocity usa and wsa. So equations (11) and (12) convert the solution of slip velocity into the solution of critical shear stress.
The resultant force of shear stress can be expressed as follows17,19 (13) The critical shear stress can be expressed as follows (14)

Figure 5(c) shows the shear stress angular ξcul, ξcdl considering the wall slip is the same as the angular reckoning without the wall slip, so wall slip do not affect relationship of the shear stress in x- and z-directions and the accuracy of the results. As shown in Figure 5(c), the critical shear stress component can be expressed as follows (15) where τcdlx, τcdlz is the critical shear stress in the x- and z-directions for slip at axial surface, ξcul, ξcdl the shear stress angular at sleeve and axial surface. Figure 5.
Shear stress vector.

In the 2D flow, both the magnitude and the direction of the slip velocity cannot be known in advance, which brings some difficulties in numerical calculation. Since the direction of slip velocity cannot be known in advance, the front of scalar usb, wsb, usa, and wsa multiplies the corresponding coefficient βculx, βculz, βcdlx, and βcdlz when the formula is derived. The regulation of positive sign for fluid shear stress is shown in Figure 5(a), negative sign is in the opposite direction. If τyx and τyz are greater than 0, βculx and βculz are 1. If τyx, τyz is less than 0, βculx and βculz are −1.

sec.title: Oil film thickness equation
sec.p: Because the surface of the spiral oil wedge hybrid sleeve bearing consists of two parts, the common surface same as conventional bearing and the circular recess surface (Figure 1) caused by three oil recesses, the oil film thickness must be calculated, respectively.
Film thickness at the common cylinder surface is written as (16)

Film thickness at the eccentric arc surface is written as (17) where e is the eccentricity, α the position angle of the eccentric arc, α=ztgβ/R, θ the attitude angle, R1 the radius of the arc surface, e1 the eccentricity of the eccentric arc, and φ the angular coordinate, φ = x/R.

sec.title: Boundary condition
sec.p: At the regions of inlet holes 2 (Figure 1), the pressure is taken to be equal to the feed lubricant pressure pin; at both ends of the bearing and the region of outlet holes 1, the pressure is taken to be equal to the ambient pressure that is defined as being zero; at the point of film rupture, the pressure boundary condition accords with the Reynolds boundary condition, that is p = 0,∂p∂φ=0.

sec.title: Numerical calculation verification
sec.p:
In the same state and calculation conditions of Ma et al.,19 it is proved whether the numerical results of 2D spiral oil wedge bearing based on critical shear stress model are right. The primary parameters of the bearing are given as follows:19 width-diameter ratio L/D is 1, eccentricity ratio ε is 0.8. As shown in Figure 6, the method results are in general consistent with the reference results except that there are some errors in small dimensionless initial critical shear stress Tcu=τcuc/(uaη). Globally, error is in the permissible range, which validates that this calculation method and the results are correct. Figure 6.
The carrying capacity and friction for literature and theoretical computation.

sec.title: Numerical solution and results
sec.p:
The finite difference method, the iteration method with over relaxation and Reynolds boundary conditions are used in solving corresponding Reynolds equations (7) to (10) that is determined according to four slip states of the grid points as shown in Figure 7, pressure distribution, carrying capacity, and flow velocity of the spiral oil wedge bearing are computed considering the wall slip. In numerical calculation, the shear stress is related with the pressure and varies over the whole bearing calculation region, so it can not be extracted from equations (7) to (10). However, solution of generalized Reynolds equation is quite straightforward using successive over-relaxation iteration method, which is consistent with references.12,14,17 The bearing within whole circumference was expanded to a plane and divided into many rectangle grids. Because, the spiral oil wedge sleeve bearing is not symmetrical in axial direction, the grids must cover the whole bearing width. With these grids, the first and second-order partial derivatives can be expressed using second order, centered finite differences around each grid. Figure 7.
Flow chart.

The primary parameters of the bearing are given as follows: rotational speed n is 10,000 r/min, bearing diameter D is 100 mm, bearing clearance c is 0.02 mm, width-diameter ratio L/D is 1.1, depth of the arc recess h0 is 0.12 mm, inlet oil pressure pin is 1 MPa, oil viscosity η is 0.02 Pa·s, oil density ρ is 876.5 kg/m3. Using the equation Re=ρuac/η for journal bearing, the Reynolds number Re is about 45.87 that is much lower than the critical Reynolds number 1000 for the transition from laminar flow to turbulent flow. So the calculation is in the condition of laminar flow.

sec.title: The influence of the bearing structure on wall slip
sec.p:
Figure 8 shows the graphical comparison of the threshold of dimensionless initial critical shear stress for spiral oil wedge bearing and conventional bearing at spiral angle β = 0.6 rad and different eccentricities. With the decrease of initial critical shear stress, bearing surfaces begin to slip and carrying capacity begins to decrease (see Figure 10) in the threshold of dimensionless initial critical shear stress. For example, the threshold of dimensionless initial critical shear stress Tcu for spiral oil wedge bearing is 2.4, but the threshold for conventional bearing is 2 at ε = 0.4, Tcu = Tcd. Figure 8 indicates that the threshold of the critical initial shear stress increases with the eccentricity increasing; at the same eccentricity, the threshold of critical shear stress for spiral oil wedge sliding bearing is higher compared with the general bearing. So the special spiral oil wedge structure and the increase of eccentricity make slip more difficult to occur, which leads to a better understanding for wall slip. Figure 8.
The initial shear stress for spiral oil wedge and conventional journal bearing. Figure 9.
Pressure for different initial shear stresses: (a) λ = 0.2; (b) λ = 0.5; and (c) λ = 0.7. Figure 10.
Carrying capacity for different initial shear stresses.

sec.title: The influence of initial critical shear stress on bearing performance
sec.p: Figure 9 is the distributions of dimensionless circumference pressure in the case of Tcd = 0.84, ε = 0.6, different dimensionless initial shear stresses of sleeve surface and dimensionless axial coordinates λ = 0.2, λ = 0.5, and λ = 0.8. The figures show that: sleeve surface begins to slip when initial shear stresses Tcu of sleeve surface is 2.75, and the oil film pressure decreases obviously with the initial shear stress decreasing; the oil film pressure considering wall slip (Tcu ≤ 2.75) is lower compared with reckoning without wall slip (Tcu > 2.75); the wall slip has effect on the oil film rupture location, for example, the oil film rupture location in the case of Tcu = 0.38 is in advance compared with reckoning without wall slip. So the cavitation area at Tcu = 0.38 increases, which affects the lubrication quality of bearing. The area of the positive pressure zone decreases and the position of pressure peak migrates along the x-negative direction when wall slip is considered, which is consistent with the decrease of carrying capacity considering wall slip.

Figures 10 and 11 are the influence of initial critical shear stress on carrying capacity and friction drag in the case of ε = 0.6 and five cases. The five cases are as following: case a, slip is only allowed to occur at the sleeve surface; case b, slip is only allowed to occur at the axis surface; case c, slip can occur at both surfaces and the initial shear stress is equal; case d, the initial shear stress of the axis surface is only fixed at 0.25, but the initial shear stress of the sleeve surface is discussed; case e, the initial shear stress of the axis surface is only fixed at 0.84, but the initial shear stress of the sleeve surface is discussed:
With the initial shear stress decreasing, slip begins to occur at sleeve surface and axis surface, and carrying capacity and friction drag decrease. According to the equation Tcu=τcuc/(uaη), the increase of journal speed and the decrease of the radial clearance can lead to the decrease of Tcu when the initial shear stress is fixed at constant (the surface property remains unchanged), so wall slip can occur drastically in the high speed and ultra high speed conditions.
In general, the carrying capacity and friction drag are maximum in case a, and the carrying capacity and friction drag are minimum in case d, so the value of carrying capacity and friction drag is too large when slip is considered only on the surface of the sleeve surface or axial surface. Slip should be considered at the both surfaces in numerical calculation of bearing performance; 3. Sleeve surface begins to slip at Tcu = Tcd = 3.18 in case c, when curves c and a coincide with each other. Axial surface begins to slip at Tcu = Tcd = 3.1, when curves c and b coincide with each other. Curves c and e coincide with each other at Tcu = Tcd = 0.84, curves c and d coincide with each other at Tcu = Tcd = 0.25.
Figure 11.
Friction for different initial shear stresses.

sec.title: Slip starting and expanding of different initial critical shear stresses
sec.p:
Figures 12(a), 13(a) and 14(a) show the graphical comparisons of Tb, Ta, Tcul, Tcdl, usb, wsb, usa, and wsa at ε = 0.6, β = 0.6, λ = 0.5, Tcd = 0.84 and Tcu varies at 3, 0.38, and 0. Figure 12(a) indicates Tb < Tcul at Tcu = 3, so wall slip can not occur (wsb = usb = 0) at the sleeve surface in Figure 12(b). Figure 12(c) shows that wall slip occurs at narrow gap, circumference slip velocity is opposite to rotation direction and the axial slip velocity is obvious at larger gap. Figure 12.
Tcu = 3, Tcd = 0.84: (a) shear stress and slip velocity; (b) slip velocity at the sleeve surface; and (c) slip velocity at the axis surface and oil film thickness contours.

Figure 13(a) shows that Tcul = Tb in the area 1, 2, 3, at Tcu = 0.38, when the sleeve surface can slip and axial slip velocity is smaller compared with the circumferential slip velocity. So in Figure 13(b), the slip velocity is about circumferential, wall slip occurs in the envelop zone, the end slip velocity is outward, the end leakage increases, carrying capacity decreases and temperature rise decreases. The axial surface can slip in the area of 4 in Figure 13(a), when Tcdl = Ta and usa > wsa. Figure 13(c) shows that the axial slip velocity is more obvious in the start slip position, the slip velocity is about circumferential in the other position, wall slip occurs in the small clearance position and the slip area of both ends is larger. The slip velocity direction changes into the axial rotation direction, the emergence of wall slip is beneficial to the increase of carrying capacity in this sense, but the general capacity is reduced considering the large area slip of sleeve surface. Figure 13.
Tcu = 0.38, Tcd = 0.84: (a) shear stress and slip velocity; (b) slip velocity at the sleeve surface; and (c) slip velocity at the axis surface and oil film thickness contours.

Figure 14(a) shows that the oil wedge can slip at Tcu = 0 and the direction of usb and wsb changes with different positions. And in Figure 14(b), the general slip velocity is about x-direction in the envelop surface, the overall slip velocity of oil wedge flows to the outlet position, so the flow rate of outlet increases and the pressure decreases. Compare Figure 14(c) with Figure 13(c), and it will be seen that the slip position of axis surface migrates along x-direction and the general slip zone changes little. In general, the bearing and shaft material has an impact on the initial shear stress, and the slip position and area influence each other in the sleeve and axial surface. Figure 14.
Tcu = 0, Tcd = 0.84: (a) shear stress and slip velocity; (b) slip velocity at the sleeve surface; and (c) slip velocity at the axis surface and oil film thickness contours.

list-item.p: The special structure of spiral oil wedge and the increase of eccentricity make slip more difficult to occur.

With the decrease of initial limiting shear stress, pressure, carrying capacity and friction drag decrease; the oil film rupture position is affected, the area of the positive pressure zone decreases and the position of pressure peak migrates along the x-negative direction when wall slip is considered; the increase of journal speed and the decrease of the radial clearance can lead to the decrease of initial shear stress, so wall slip can occur drastically in the high speed and ultra high speed conditions; the value of carrying capacity and friction drag is too large when slip is considered only on the surface of the sleeve surface or axial surface, so slip should be considered at the both surfaces in numerical calculation of bearing performance.

Wall slip occurs first in the large shear stresses, the small clearance and the envelop zone; the axial slip velocity is more obvious in some positions, so the circumferential and axial wall slip is considered in numerical calculation; the slip position and area influence each other in the sleeve and axial surface.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This study was supported by a grant from the Major State Basic Research Development Program of China (973 Program) (grant no. 2009CB724404) and National Nature Science Foundation of China (grant no. 51075242).
